title: IT’S MY BIRTHDAY (and I’ll cry if I want to)
description:
by Kathryn Colas –

I’ve lived a long and varied life, with its ups and downs, as you’d expect. But menopause? That’s a whole other story, and I’m still talking about it today because…

In the 1860s (you can see where this is going…), I wouldn’t have been allowed to stand up in front of an audience and talk about menopause. I didn’t even have the vote.

A hundred years later, in the 1960s, I still wouldn’t have been permitted to speak publicly about menopause. Worse, I could have been ‘sectioned’ under the Mental Health Act because of it.

In 1989, the British Menopause Society (BMS) was founded. Twenty-eight years later, in 2007, I joined the BMS to learn more about menopause. The internet was still in its infancy, but I created the SimplyHormones website to make sense of menopause. Could I have been ‘sectioned’ for menopause in 1989? My husband might jokingly say he’d have supported that!

Also in 2007, my target audience wasn’t even online, but I pursued my passion because no one was telling women – or anyone else – what they needed to know. Around that time, I connected with MPs, Members of the House of Lords, and clinical professors. I learned how the political and medical systems work when you’re brave enough to stand up and be counted. During this period, I was invited to speak on BBC Radio 4’s Woman’s Hour, BBC Breakfast, ITV’s This Morning, and other media channels.

By 2015, recognised as a pioneer in menopause support, I launched the UK’s first menopause-in-the-workplace training programme, advocating for continuous education for everyone connected to women’s health, especially those navigating menopause.

That same year, a forward-thinking UK government appointed Ros Altmann as Pensions Minister, a champion of social justice and an advocate for ongoing training in an aging workforce. Honoured with a CBE in the 2014 Birthday Honours List, she’s now a peer in the House of Lords. She’s had a very distinguished career and I admire her greatly – she brought about a lot of change. We had some great email conversations at the time.

Another hero of mine was Teresa Gorman, an MP in the 1970s, known for her yellow jacket in the House of Commons. A self-described maverick, she openly endorsed Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT). I loved her rebellious spirit. I met her around 2010 in Billericay, Essex, her constituency. A businesswoman who got things done, she was a bit like Marmite – loved or loathed. Sadly, she passed away in 2015.

In the 2020s, Carolyn Harris (Labour MP) and Caroline Nokes (Conservative MP) worked cross-party on women’s equality. They made great strides, but the final bill was significantly watered down.

In 2025, I met my local MP, Mims Davies, currently Shadow Minister for Women and a passionate advocate for women’s equality. She’s approachable, walks the walk, and must be a bit of a rebel too- I like her!

For me, it’s come full circle. When COVID stopped the world in 2020, it was, from a business perspective, my best year ever. I had just launched my book, How to Survive Menopause Without Losing Your Mind – the title hints at the impact menopause had on me. But then my business crashed, so I started a new one, as you do! This evolved into the Kathryn Colas Menopause Academy, where we blend live, online, and digital platforms with a holistic approach to the health of women, their partners, families, and colleagues. You should take a look!

Menopause is more than the end of reproduction – it’s a systemic transition affecting the entire body. You could even call it symbiotic, reflecting the interaction between cells.

Recently, I watched a podcast with Dr. Louise Newson and Dr. Karan Rajan, where I learned that young women undergoing surgical menopause are rarely offered HRT- less than 5% receive it post-hysterectomy, and 0% are offered testosterone. The NICE Guidelines are clear, yet doctors often ignore them, leaving these women uninformed and struggling. Dr. Newson’s husband, a surgeon I believe, noted that men undergoing similar procedures (e.g., testicle removal) are routinely prescribed testosterone to address symptoms like brain fog, reduced memory, and poor concentration – symptoms women also experience during menopause, whether surgical or natural. This double standard isn’t good enough. Both procedures are medically termed castration and should be treated with equal consideration.

In the same interview, both doctors agreed that clinicians and surgeons generally seem to have tunnel vision. They don’t see the ramifications beyond treating the target organ.

When it comes to women’s health, we must take a holistic view – physiologically and psychologically – connecting the dots for better health and longer lives. This isn’t airy-fairy stuff; it’s about seeing the body as a whole.

My work continues. Birthday or not, I’m still outrageously passionate about women’s health, especially during and beyond menopause. Through my own experience, I’ve learned that a little knowledge goes a long way, and women should be thriving through menopause (the title of my next book, coming soon!).

I don’t want to end on a sad note, but so much research concludes with, “more research is needed.” So, I’ll cry if I want to, but you won’t see me crying, even if I’ve cried a river. Let’s celebrate and shout!

Lyrical nods to:
“It’s My Party” by Lesley Gore
“You Won’t See Me Crying” by Passage
“Cry Me a River” by Julie London (1953)
“Shout” by the effervescent Lulu

The post IT’S MY BIRTHDAY (and I’ll cry if I want to) first appeared on Simply Hormones.
